p: Two double-blind RCTs enrolled adult patients with HIV (CQ 150–300 mg base/d, 8–12 weeks) [ 21, 22] and one open-label trial enrolled paediatric patients (CQ 4 mg/kg/d for 24 weeks) [ 19]. The smallest trial had 13 patients [ 22] while the largest had 70 patients [ 21]. The comparators were either placebo [ 21, 22] or zidovudine plus didanosine (paediatric trial) [ 19]. Both adult trials enrolled patients with a CD4 cell count of at least 250/μL and demonstrated a modestly beneficial immunomodulatory effect of CQ (a significant decline in activated CD8 cells) [ 21, 22]. However, in one trial which had a complex cross-over design, the HIV viral load increased when CQ was administered without any other antiretroviral therapy [ 21]. There was no significant virological or immunological improvement with CQ in the third (paediatric) trial [ 19] but significantly more gastrointestinal adverse events were observed with CQ.
